questions.answer_description: N7010-C1 cannot ping 192.168.10.91 because it lacks a Layer 2 address to which to map.

Bits -1 layer -

Frames - 2 layer -

Segments - 4 layer -
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OSI_model
questions.question_text: Which three terms are used to describe data at Layers 1, 2, and 4 of the OSI model? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: It could be debated that both sequence and segment are correct. At layer 4, the PDU is called a segment, BUT, layer 4 also does sequencing of packets. Another bad Cisco question.
I'm not sure what's going on with this one. I don't even see 192.168.10.91 in the output of show ip arp. Can you provide more detail about what we should look for?

choices.E: Consult the MAC address table (for outgoing interface) and then consult the ARP table (for the MAC address)
choices.D: Consult the routing table (for the next-hop address), and then consult the ARP table (for the MAC address)
choices.A: Consult the MAC address table (for outgoing interface) and then consult the routing table (for the next-hop address)
choices.C: Consult the ARP table (for the MAC address) and then consult the routing table (for the next-hop address)
choices.B: Consult the routing table (for the next-hop address), and then consult the MAC address table (for the outgoing interface)

discussion.content: A default route is always "quad zero's" with a /0 mask. And, a default route would never use Null0 as the next hop address. Null0 is a "bit bucket" that's used to avoid black-hole routing.

choices.E: Send an ICMP unreachable message back to the source.
choices.A: Flood the packet out of every port.

questions.question_text: Which action will a router take if it does not know the destination MAC address of a host?

discussion.content: Don't complicate this. A router is just another host on the LAN. It does the same same thing any other host would do. Sends an ARP request.
